characters: WING DID A THING LIKE THAT

dialogues.speaker: CU
dialogues.text: He is a sharp-eyed, steady veteran flyer.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA PULLS BACK
dialogues.text: showing MAJOR KONG, absorbed in a copy of "Plaything" magazine and absently munching a sandwich.  We feature a photograph.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPH
dialogues.text: Miss Milky Way, Plaything of the Month, a top government stenographer and part-time model.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA PULLS BACK
dialogues.text: showing CAPTAIN "ACE" ANGST, the co-pilot, reading anothe copy of "Plaything" and taking healthy bites out of an apple.  He is a lean, bronzed, muscular type. The plane cruises on auto-pilot. 8a   NAVIGATOR - LIEUTENANT "BINKY" BALLMUFF - READS "PLA A burly, hoarse-voiced man in his early thirties, he sips coffee and chews on his sandwich. 8b   RADIO-RADAR- LIEUTENANT TERRY TOEJAM - READS "SUNSHI

dialogues.speaker: AND LOVE"
dialogues.text: A tall, curly-haired, meticulous man in his late twenties he nibbles a piece of cake. 8c   BOMBARDIER - LIEUTENANT LOTHAR ZOGG - A NEGRO A short, bull-necked man in his early thirties, smoking and dunking a cake.  He reads "Nitelife" magazine. 8d   D.S.O. - LIEUTENANT QUENTIN QUIFFER - READS "HI-JINK The Defense Systems Officer, LIEUTENANT QUENTIN QUIFFER, a blond, pleasant mid-Westerner.  He eats chocolate crackers from a box. 8e   NAVIGATOR - LIEUTENANT "BINKY" BALLMUFF He idly glances at his charts without putting down his copy of "Plaything" and snaps his intercom button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three minutes to turning point.  Heading will be three-three-five. (back to "Plaything") 8f   MS - PILOT - MAJOR "KING" KONG He glances up from his copy of "Plaything" and with the easy grace of a veteran pilot, leans forward and changes his gyro heading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger.  Heading three-three-five. (back to "Plaything") 8g   CU - RADARSCOPE There are a number of them.  This one is the maximum search radar.  The outer rim of the scope reveals a small point of light.  At the same moment an electronic tone alarm directs the attention of the D.S.O. from his reading to the scope. 8h   CU - D.S.O. LIEUTENANT QUENTIN QUIFFER LOOKING UP

dialogues.speaker: FROM "HI-JINKS"
dialogues.text: He studies the scope calmly and frowns. 8i   CU - RADARSCOPE The D.S.O. moves a strobe marker to the blip. 8j   CU - D.S.O. Quickly figuring on pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (routinely) Bogey at one-four-five, approximately a hundred and thirty-five miles. 8k   CU - NAVIGATOR - LIEUTENANT "BINKY" BALLMUFF Turning his copy of "Plaything" over so as not to lose his place, plots a position.  We see that the radar contact is between the "Leper Colony" and the enemy coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably another radar surveillance job. 8l   CU - PILOT Without looking up from his copy of "Plaything".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (absently) Yes, that's probably what it is. 8m   CLOSE RADARSCOPE The blip suddenly vanishes as the scope goes completely white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) He's showing off his ECM - jamming us out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still absorbed in "Plaything") I wonder why he's doing that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking the same thing.  Shall I give him a taste of ours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still reading) Why should we do that, Quentin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (goes back to "Plaything") Yes, I suppose you're right, King. 8n   CU - THE CRM - 114 This is the most highly guarded Air Command secret device It is an automatic code receiver which displays three letters and three numerals. It suddenly whirrs and clicks into life, displaying three letters and three numerals. 8o   CU - LIEUTENANT TERRY TOEJAM Looks up slowly from his magazine, leans forward and jots down the coded message.  He carefully flips through a code book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Kong, we got a message from base. 8p   CU - PILOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still reading) Good. 8q   MS - LIEUTENANT TOEJAM RAPIDLY DECODES THE MESSAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've decoded it, Major Kong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reads: Wing to hold at X-points. 8r   CUTS TO CREW The magazines are lowered in slow motion. 8s   CU - BOMBARDIER - LIEUTENANT LOTHAR ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into intercom) I wonder why the're doing that. 8t   CU - PILOT - MAJOR "KING" KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wisely) They have their reasons. 8u   CU - NAVIGATOR - LIEUTENANT "BINKY" BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we've been up fourteen hours.  I'm beat. 8v   CUTS TO CREW Who mumble ad-libs of agreement with the Navigator. Then slowly, each man goes back to his magazine and his lunch. 8w   CU - LIEUTENANT LOTHAR ZOGG - READING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing) Probably an exercise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) They have their reasons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now the six-man crew is still again, pondering the mysteries of beautiful women and calmly digesting their lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wistfully to co-pilot) Ace, do you think she's really a top government secretary? He refers to the double fold-out of Miss Milky Way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cynically) Yeah, I'll bet she holds the world's horizontal short-hand record.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE TITLE
dialogues.text: HEADQUARTERS 843rd BOMB WING"

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: While the Wing is air-borne, the staff work is heavy, and the ground crews work overtime to refit aircraft.  The runways are clear, and only the giant cicadas and the occasional whine of an electric tool break the stillness of the starry desert night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is sunken fifty feet below the administration building.  Six officers man the command bridge. A loud buzzer. MAJOR MANDRAKE lifts special phone. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Combat Operations Center, Major Mandrake speaking. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is General Ripper speaking. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you recognize my voice? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, General.  Why do you ask, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large, plush, part Air Force, part big executive - swank office decorations and furniture.  A name-plate on his desk reads, "General Jack D. Ripper". GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) Why do you think I ask? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, sir. We just spoke a few minutes ago. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ruffled) Youddon't think I'd ask if you recognized my voice unless it was important, do you, Major? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. The scene will intercut between MANDRAKE and RIPPER. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Has the Wing confirmed holding at X-points? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Major.  I'm putting the base on condition Red. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Condition Red! GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  I want this flashed to all section immediately. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  What's up, General Ripper? A significant pause. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good officer, Major Mandrake.  You have a right to know.  It looks like we're in a shooting war! MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shooting war! GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Major.  This looks like it's going to be it. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...what kind of a shooting war?  Have they hit any of our cities yet? GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major, that's all I've been told.  Just got it on the red phone.  The base is to be sealed tight.  And I mean tight. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That includes all communications and phones - incoming as well as outgoing. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if someone wants to call us? GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me worry about that, Major. I've still got my red line to the Air Command. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, sir. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't want to be vulnerable to saboteurs calling up and pretending to be different people from the President down, do we? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, sir. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No calls from inside out.  No calls from outside in are even answered.  No calls. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand, sir.  Nothing comes or goes without your personal say-so. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) No calls at all.  With or without my say-so. My voice can be imitated too, Major. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  I just thought of something, sir.  How do I know I'm talking to you now? GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think you're talking to? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To you, sir.  But how do I know? GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to be insubordinate? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope not.  Now, as soon as you do what I told you, have Plan-R radioed to the Wing. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plan-R???? GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you hard of hearing, Major? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.  Plan-R to be radioed to the Wing. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as you've done that, shut down the communications center.  Lock it up and assign the personnel to base security details. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Ripper, if I shut down the communi- cations center, there'll be no radio or teleprinter contact with Air Command head- quarters or anyone, for that matter. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you questioning my orders, Major? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.  I'm just bringing the facts to your attention, sir. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good officer, Major, and you're perfectly right to bring these facts to my attention. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, as soon as you've done that, double- up on all base security teams.  Our enemies are plenty smart, and there might even be an attack on the base by saboteurs. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. GENERAL JACK D. RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And lastly, all privately owned radios are to be immediately impounded.  They can be used to issue instructions to saboteurs. Air Police will have lists of all owners.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The crew is still wistfully absorbed in their magazines. 13a  CU - CRM-114 It whirrs to life again.  Clicking off three letters and three numerals. 13b  CU - LT. TOEJAM - RADIO He idly glances up at it.  Sighs, reaches for his code bo and starts decoding.  He frowns. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, King.  Somebody at Burpelson has a very perverted sense of humor. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Yeah? LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got another blast on the CRM-114, and the damned thing decodes: Wing Attack, Plan-R. 13c  CU - PILOT - MAJOR "KING" KONG He looks up pensively. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wing attack, Plan-R? 13d  MASTER SHOT LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wing attack, Plan-R.  That's exactly what it says. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lets magazine fall in lap) Check your code again.  No one at base would pull a stunt like that, Terry. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm doing, and it comes out the same. There is a pause as they think of the unthinkable. LT. "BINKY" BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) You must have made a mistake. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what it decodes.  Come and see for yourself, Binky.  Wing attack, Plan-R. The whole crew comes up and hunches over the CRM-114. The plane cruises on auto-pilot. LT. LOTHAR ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Well, I'll be damned. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding out code book to pilot) Here, check it yourself. 13e  CU - MAJOR KONG His cheek muscles twitch under his bronzed face.  He is t of leadership.  He turns away from the men for a moment, thoughtfully into space, then turns back determinedly. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with quiet dignity) Then this is it. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solemnly) War. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awe-struck) War? CAPTAIN ANGST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding gravely) Yes, that must be what it is. LT. BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aghast) War? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) What else could it be? LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's an exercise. LT. BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, to see if we're on our toes. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wisely) No, they wouldn't send us in with bombs on an exercise. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they want to test our loyalty. CAPTAIN ANGST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we got the Go-code.  It's never been given to anyone before. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scowling) No, this looks like the real thing. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (philosophically) Yeah, it sure looks like the real thing, all right. They all soberly reflect on the wider implications of the news.  The BOMBARDIER cracks his knuckles. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) It's going to be rough on the folks back home. LT. BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah - real rough. They all shake their heads in melancholy agreement. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder how it started? CAPTAIN ANGST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, how could it have started? THE D.S.O. shatter the calm dignity of the crew by raisin his voice. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bastards must have hit us! LT. BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah - but why would they do that, Quentin? LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know?  But they must have.  We wouldn't have started it. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right.  We wouldn't have started it. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beginning to shout) They must have clobbered some of our cities already! LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right.  They must have clobbered some of our cities already. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dirty, stinking, rotten, sons of B's!! They might have clobbered Marge and the LT. QUIFFER (cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: kids already! 13f  CU - MAJOR KONG He studies LT. QUIFFER with a jaundiced look. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (John Wayne) Okay, cut it, Lieutenant Quiffer!  If you speak once more before I give you per- mission, you'll face a general court martial when we get back. (looks around) And that goes for everyone else. He pauses for effect. 13g  CU - D.S.O. LIEUTENANT QUENTIN QUIFFER looks down sheepishly. 13h  CU - MAJOR KONG MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (John Wayne) Boys, we've got a mission to carry out. It's not exactly a pleasant one, but our country's counting on us, and we're not going to let 'em down. 13i  FULL SHOT - THE CREW LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Major Kong.  I guess I was way out of line. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extending his hand) Forget it, Quentin.  It can happen to the best of us.  Now let's get squared away. With various ad libs of agreement, the crew scramble back to their action stations. 13j  VARIOUS SHOTS - CREW LIEUTENANT BALLMUFF opens a small safe and searches out a thick 8 x 10 sealed envelope marked "Plan-R", from among dozen others. He shoots an inquiring look to the pilot and gets a nod. He breaks open the seal and distributes individual folder to each of the crew. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a first rough course as soon as you can, Lieutenant Ballmuff. LT. BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roughly, one-zero-five. I'll have it plotted in a minute, Major Kong. 13k  MS - MAJOR KONG He adjusts the gyro, banks the big plane, and opens his f MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from his folder) Okay.  Check these points.  Complete radio silence.  To ensure that the enemy can't plant false transmissions and fake orders, the CRM-114 is to be switched into all receiver circuits.  The three code letters of the period are to be set on the alphabet dials of the CRM-114, which will in turn block any transmissions other than those preceded by the code letters. You got it? LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger, I'm setting up the CRM-114. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primary target the ICBM base at Laputa. One weapon fused for air burst at ten thou- sand.  Second weapon to be used if first malfunctions.  Otherwise the secondary gets it - the airfield outside of Karnak.  Fused air burst at ten thousand. LT. BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the heading, Major.  One-three-eight. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger. One-three-eight. While he talks, other CUTS to the crew prepraring for bat MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In about twenty minutes we start losing height to keep under coastal radar.  Cross in over the coast low-level, continue low- level on zig-zag legs to primary, and climb for bomb run. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any questions? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got one. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot, Lothar. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our targets are a missile complex and an airfield - not cities, right? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I said. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if there's a war, they must have hit us first. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your point, Lothar? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if they hit us first, they've probably fired off their missiles and got their planes off the ground already.  We'll just be hitting empty real estate. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying our order don't make sense? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hellnno, Major.  I was just trying to think the thing through. MAJOR "KING" KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lothar, you're down in the pay books as a bombardier, and you're a damned good bombardier.  In fact, you're the best damned bombardier in 843rd Wing. 14 15 15a  COLONEL PUNTRICH He sits at a table a phone.  Six other officers are around him. COLONEL PUNTRICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?  This is Colonel Puntrich of Air Command Headquarters.  Please connect me with General "Buck" Schmuck.

dialogues.speaker: SWITCHBOARD IN HOTEL
dialogues.text: The night GIRL is reading a paperback murder mystery. SWITCHBOARD OPERATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir.  General Schmuck is asleep and he isn't taking calls until eight-thirty. COLONEL PUNTRICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your name, young lady? SWITCHBOARD OPERATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ceida Pietraszkiewicz. COLONEL PUNTRICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say? SWITCHBOARD OPERATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ceida Pietraszkiewicz...P...I...E... T...R...A...S...Z...K...I...E...W... I...C...Z. COLONEL PUNTRICH (he pronounces it perfectly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look here, Miss Pietraszkiewicz, this is Air Command Headquarters calling.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Phone rings.  He wakes slowly, coughing from too many cigarettes.  He snaps on the bed lamp and picks up the phone.  The night table contains tissues, nose drops, and a glass of water.  There is a pretty blonde asleep in the next bed, Miss Milky Way, Plaything of the Month! GENERAL SCHMUCK (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! COLONEL PUNTRICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Schmuck? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!  Who the hell is this? Miss MILKY WAY, about nineteen, appears from under the blankets of the adjoining twin bed.  She yawns and stretc revealing her astonishing body.  She is indeed the same g we saw featured in the "Plaything" fold-out-inside the B- COLONEL PUNTRICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Colonel Puntrich, sir.  Duty officer at Air Command.  I'm sorry to disturb you, sir. MILKY WAY (yawning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it, Buck, honey? GENERAL SCHMUCK (covering mouthpiece)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to sleep, baby. COLONEL PUNTRICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say, sir? She smiles, crosses over next to the General, and begins playing with his ear.  He shrugs her off, playfully. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say anything.  What's the meaning of disturbing me at this hour, Colonel? COLONEL PUNTRICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Schmuck, we monitored a trans- mission about six minutes ago from Burpelson Air Force Base, HQ 843rd Wing.  It was apparently directed to their Wing on air- borne alert.  It decoded as - Wing attack, Plan-R. She begins kissing his neck. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, you're not drunk, are you, man? COLONEL PUNTRICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why bother me with this nonsense? Get in touch with the base commander. She pulls him flat on the bed. COLONEL PUNTRICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We tried to contact General Jack D. Ripper at the base, but all their communications are dead, sir. She sprawls on top of him. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's ridiculous.  If the teleprinter and radio links are out of order, just pick up a phone and pay for a call. COLONEL PUNTRICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it sounds crazy, sir, but we tried, and nobody answers any of the telephones. GENERAL SCHMUCK sits up. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the threat board show anything? COLONEL PUNTRICH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's the funny part of it, too, sir.  It doesn't show a damned thing.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Buttoning-up activity continues as the men listen to the GENERAL's broadcast echoing on a public address system. GENERAL RIPPER (public address system)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to impress on you the need for watchfulness.  A commie will try any trick to breach the security on this base.

dialogues.speaker: PERIMETER FENCE
dialogues.text: Digging in a machine gun about ten yards outside fence. The riflemen are spread out at 5-year intervals and are digging foxholes. GENERAL RIPPER (p.a.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He may come individually, or he may come in strength.  He may come in the uniform of our own troops.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER AREA
dialogues.text: They set up another light-machine gun.  A squad of riflem dig in too. GENERAL RIPPER (p.a.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust no one, whatever his rank, who is not known to you personally.

dialogues.speaker: AIR POLICE
dialogues.text: Collecting radios. GENERAL RIPPER (p.a.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone or anything that approaches within two hundred yards of the perimeter is to be fired upon - without challenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last of the staff are leaving. GENERAL RIPPER (p.a.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are to be no exceptions to these orders.  Last of all, I want to say I know all of you are worrying about your families here on the base and all over the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can be sure other men are defending your families elsewhere with the same unyielding spirit we're going to show here at Burpelson.  Good luck to you all. RIPPER flicks the mike button and sinks wearily back into his chair.  He lights a cigarette and inhales with satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snaps off his desk lamp and walks down the long, deserted room, double-clicking various power switches. He picks up a small transistor radio and idly snaps it on A pop song ends and a disc jockey begins his commercial. 26a  CLOSE - MAJOR MANDRAKE He tunes in a few other stations.  All programs are norma MANDRAKE frowns, thinks for a moment, and suddenly dashes out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Key personnel begin to arrive in cars which screech to st

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Officers hurrying to their tasks.  M.P.'S guard re- stricted areas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very large conference room.  One wall is an enormous soundproof glass panel opening onto the various electroni displays in the War Room. Enter, PRESIENT MERKIN MUFFLEY, in a fury. Rising around a very large, polished wood conference tabl are the Chiefs of Staff, Army, Navy, and Air Force, as we as various military and civilian senior aides - about twenty altogether. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY (seething)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, gentlemen.  Please sit down. They sit. There are readable nameplates in front of each officer. GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mister President. The PRESIDENT scowls. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, what the hell's going on? Four-Star Air Force General, "BUCK" SCHMUCK, stands and assumes his maximum dignity. GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mister President. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of trouble? GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, about forty-six minutes ago one of my base commanders, General Jack D. Ripper, sent out attack orders to the thirty-four B-90's of the 843rd Bomb Wing, under his command. Note:  1.  The name Schmuck appears on page 1431 of the 1 Manhattan Telephone Directory. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Schmuck? GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  He issued attack orders to -- A paroxysm of rage seizes the President, MERKIN MUFFLEY, pounds his fist on the table, knocking over his nameplate PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I be stupid enough to inquire WHY IN HELL THE BASE COMMANDER OF THE 843d BOMB

dialogues.speaker: WING DID A THING LIKE THAT
dialogues.text: GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be perfectly honest, Mister President, we really aren't sure. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You aren't sure! GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly, sir.  You see, Colonel Puntrich at Air Command HQ received a call from him about twenty minutes ago.  He asked General Ripper if he had issued the Go-code and the attack order, and General Ripper said: (he reads from a piece of paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sure, the orders came from me.  They're on their way in, and I advise you to get the rest of Air Command in after them. My boys will give you the best kind of start, and you sure as hell won't stop them now."  Then he hung up. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it!  Damn it!  I've been telling you all for years you've got too damned many psychoes in the service. GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be fair, Mister President.  Didn't we initiate the Human Reliability tests for all personnel handling nuclear weapons? PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck, when I told you to give them right up to the top, you said we couldn't insult a general officer by asking him to pass a test to see if he's a psycho. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a honest mistake, sir. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I presume the planes are armed? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so, Mister Presient. Being part of the air-borne alert, each plane is carrying a full load - about fifty megatons apiece. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what about the Positive Control, the safety catch?  Don't the planes automatically come back unless they get a second order? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, sir.  But the planes were at their Positive Control points, ready to turn around when General Ripper issued the final Go-code. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I suppose there's some reason why you haven't recalled them? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  The base commander, General Ripper, selected Plan-R? PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is Plan-R? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, Plan-R is an emergency plan to be used by lower echelon commanders if higher echelons have been knocked out by a sneak attack. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't you cancel it? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once the orders have been given, Plan-R requires any new orders to be received on the CRM-114 in the aircraft.  But the CRM-114 will not receive any transmissions unless they are preceded by the proper three-letter code group. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I suppose you're going to tell me you don't know what the three-letter code is. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister President, to guard against espionage, the three letter of the code group for Plan-R are always selected by the lower echelon commander himself, just before each mission.  They are sealed in the various attack plans and are known only to the lower echelon commander and his deputy.  In this case the deputy is air-borne with the Wing, and General Ripper refuses to recall the planes. The PRESIDENT shakes his head, wrathfully. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How soon until the enemy finds out what's going on? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We estimate the planes should be entering their coastal radar cover in about twenty-five min- utes. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you let this happen, General Schmuck? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister President, I know you think I've let you down, but we had to have a Plan-R.  If we completely centralized the command and control, all a potential aggressor would have to worry about was knock- ing out maybe half a dozen headquarters and the Capitol, and we'd be out of business. We'd have planes and missiles just sitting there while we were getting clobbered. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then there's no chance for recall? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should say practically none, though we have our communications center plowing through every possible three-letter combination. The trouble is that there are about seventeen thousand permutations, and it will take us approximately four and a half days to go through them all. There is a knock at the door. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, what is it? M.P. CAPTAIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir.  But the mess orderlies are outside with the breakfasts everyone ordered. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waspishly) Captain, do you think the mess orderlies would mind waiting a few minutes until we have finished our little meeting? M.P. CAPTAIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) No, sir...I mean, yes, sir. I'm sure they wouldn't. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) Thank you, Captain.  Now shut the damned door! He shuts the door. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY (Cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk to the base commander, what's his name? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Jack D. Ripper, sir. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk to General Ripper. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we can't communicate with the base. The PRESIDENT leans back and thinks for a moment. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Faceman, are there any troops stationed near the base who are not under General Ripper's command? All eyes go to GENERAL "FLASH" FACEMAN, the Army Chief. GENERAL "FLASH" FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe so, Mister President. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in burning sarcasm) Is it possible for you to know definitely, General? GENERAL "FLASH" FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  I can confirm it, but I believe there's a Special Services outfit stationed just on the other side of town, about seven miles away. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Faceman, I want you to get on the phone yourself and speak to the officer in charge -- GENERAL  FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rapid fire) Please don't say "yes, sir" until I've finished speaking.  Tell him to get himself and his men moving immediately.  I don't even want them to waste time dressing.  Just have them carry their weapons and ammunition, and move 'em out by any available means of transportation. If they don't have enough vehicles, commandeer cars off the highway. I want them there within fifteen minutes.  And if he can't get them all there, get as many as he can. I want them to enter the base, locate General Ripper, and immediately put him in telephone contact with me. You understand, don't you, General? GENERAL FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts out of room) Yes, sir.  One thing, Mister President. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? GENERAL FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under a condition red alert, the base will probably be sealed off and defended by the base security troops. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am aware of what a condition red alert implies. GENERAL FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, they may not allow the Special Service troops to enter the base. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) That's a very wise deduction, General. GENERAL FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.  But what shall I tell them to do if they are denied entrance? The PRESIDENT rocks in his chair looking as if he were ab to explode. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the circumstances, General, what would you think they should do? GENERAL FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...I suppose penetrate the base by force. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, you knew the answer all the time, General. GENERAL FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that would mean some of our own boys will get hurt, Mister President. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you suppose is going to happen if General Ripper's planes start bombing their targets? GENERAL FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That certainly would be a problem, sir. CADAVERLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister President, how do you feel about Civil Defense? PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Civil Defense...Hm-mmm...We don't want to cause an unnecessary panic. CADAVERLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we allow the situation to mature a bit, sir? PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I think that's the wisest policy for the moment.

dialogues.speaker: B-90 STING RAY
dialogues.text: Tilting down toward the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LT. BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (navigator) Make rate of descent fifteen hundred per minute.  That should slide us in nicely under their radar cover. MAJOR KONG adjusts trim, throttling back slightly to main correct speed.  We see the rate of descent indicator stea at 1500, speed steady at Mach one-three on the Machmeter. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady at fifteen hundred per minute. Speed steady at Mach one-three. The navigator, LT. BALLMUFF, glances at his Ground Positi Indicator, on which certain of the pilot's instruments ar duplicated. LT. BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger, maintain. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lothar, take your checks now. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Major. LT. ZOGG, the Negro bombardier, is sitting in the midst o his equipment, which comprises several radioscopes and a battery of buttons and switch gear, as well as several ba rows of lights.  He goes through the checks quickly, at e wit the familiar equipment and a familiar task. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Main search radar all green.  Set for maximum range, maximum sweep. Again CUT between the pilot and bombardier, as bombardier calls each piece of equipment in turn, and pilot checks t on his list. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both electronic detectors set to swing from stud A through H. We see, on the bulky electronic detector, a small rotor arm moving rapidly through the sequence of stud settings, and flicking back to start again. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A through H is correct. LT. QUIFFER (D.S.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Main interference linked to electronic detector.  Fight interference on readi- ness state. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missile and plane flight path computer showing four greens. We see the four lights winking on an off in rotation on the computer. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zombies set to knock out local air defense four hundred miles from primary. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Target approach radar tuning is right. All approach transparencies are checked, one through twenty-five. We see bombardier take one of the transparencies, slide i approach radarscope. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check target approach. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bomb doors circuit is green, bomb release circuit is green, bomb fusing circuit is green. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check, all bomb circuits green.  Okay, Lothar. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do you want to arm the bomb for the primary, Major? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as I've checked over the route. About five minutes.  All right? LT. BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In thirty seconds count-down clock should read eight-three minutes, King. 32a  COUNT-DOWN CLOCK Pilot's hand sets clock to "83"

dialogues.speaker: DAWN
dialogues.text: All the security details are in position, and everything a peaceful hush.

dialogues.speaker: CU
dialogues.text: He gestures with the gun in a weirdly amiable way. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Major Mandrake. 34a  MASTER SHOT MAJOR MANDRAKE closes the door behind him and sits. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling nervously) What's the gun for, General Ripper? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't take any notice of this weapon, Major.  I love all weapons, and as of late, I've just taken to keeping a loaded weapon nearby at all times. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs shakily) Sort of like a new hobby, huh, General? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Major. MAJOR MANDRAKE still holds the little transistor radio wh plays a rock and roll tune.  He smiles, idiotically. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I see you're playing your radio, Major. Isn't that contrary to my instructions for the personnel of this base? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's not my radio, sir.  I picked it up in the communications center. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean for anyone to play anyone else's radio either, Major. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  General, can I ask a question? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, Major Mandrake.  You're a good officer, and you can ask me a question any time you want to. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, General Ripper, sir -- I was thinking -- we're on a condition red, aren't we? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is correct, Major. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a condition red means enemy attack in progress, doesn't it? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the regulations well, Major. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, I was thinking, if an enemy attack is in progress, how come the radio's still playing music?  It's supposed to go off, and all we should hear are Civil Defense broadcasts. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good question, Major.  Maybe if you think hard, you can think of the answer yourself. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (timidly) Well, I was thinking, maybe an enemy attack is not in progress? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if that were true? MAJOR MANDRAKE wrinkles his forehead apprehensively. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cautiously) But then, sir, why have you issued the order: Wing attack, Plan-R? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I thought it proper, Major.  Why else would you think I'd do it? 34b  CU - MAJOR MANDRAKE - AS THE FULL TRUTH SINKS IN MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you are...starting...the War, sir? 34c  MASTER SHOT GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose that were the case? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awe-struck) But -- why...that would be an awful thing to do, sir. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps, Major.  Perhaps.  Pour me a scotch and soda, please.  And help yourself to whatever you like. MAJOR MANDRAKE rises unsteadily and goes to the built-in GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fret about it, Major.  There's nothing anyone can do about it now.  I'm the only one who knows the three-letter code group for the CRM-114. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that, sir. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've come a long way since World War II, Major.  And the lessons we've learned are all in Plan-R. MANDRAKE's hands tremble as he pours the drinks. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose they are, sir. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're damned right they are. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much soda, sir. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a squirt. He gives a squirt. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That about right? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (accepting drink) Perfect.  Thank you, Major.  And now let's drink a toast. MAJOR MANDRAKE pours himself a big slug and keeps it stra MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his glass) What shall we drink to, sir? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with the eyes of a zealot) To peace on earth. They touch glasses. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Ripper, can I ask another question? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask away, Major. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, General -- I was wondering, why are you doing this?  I mean why do you want to start the war? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've given it alot of thought, Major.  Don't think I haven't. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.  I mean I didn't think you hadn't given it a lot of thought. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember what Clemenceau once said about war? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, sir. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said war was too important a matter to be left to Generals. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he said it, fifty years ago, he might have been right.  But today, war is too important to be left to the politicians. Do you follow me, Major? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to, sir. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Major, at this very moment, while we sit and chat, a decision is being made by the President in the War Room.  He knows that the enemy will pick up our planes on their radar in about twenty minutes. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when they do, sir, won't they hit back with everything they've got? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we haven't taken any further action, they certainly will.  Doyyourhappen to remember the statistics on our casualties in the event of a full-scale enemy attack? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think I remember reading the report on that.  Wasn't it something like a hundred and sixty million? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's close enough, Major. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then why do you want to kill a hundred and sixty million of our people, sir? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're being dense, Major.  I certainly don't GENERAL RIPPER (Cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: want to kill so many of our people.  And neither does the President.  Now look, Major Mandrake.  What happens if the President immediately orders our entire missile force to hit enemy airfields, missiles and bases? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose we might catch them off their guard. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our missiles would impact before my planes were even discovered by the enemy, wouldn't they? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know so, Major.  I know so.  And add to that, the whole Air Command force being committed to clobber everything they've got. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But even then, we wouldn't get everything.  I mean some missiles would abort, or they'd miss their targets, or maybe the enemy have some secret bases we don't know about. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're absolutely right.  You forgot to mention their nuclear subs.  But it wouldn't matter. Sure we wouldn't get off without getting our hair mussed, but we'd prevail.  I don't think we'd lose more than fifty million people, tops. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitatingly) But if you just let things alone, we wouldn't lose anyone. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Mandrake, I guess you don't follow what's going on too closely, do you? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where, sir? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles patronisingly) Where?  Everywhere, Major.  Everywhere. MAJOR MANDRAKE nods, blankly. GENERAL RIPPER (Cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you read much about the disarmament talks, Major? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I know they've been going on for years, and they haven't gotten any place. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet, Major.  Not yet. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I guess they won't until they agree to let us inspect inside their country. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very naive, Major.  Don't they say they want disarmament? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  But so do we. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we mean it because we are a peace- loving country.  Are they a peace-loving country, Major. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, sir.  But they're just as anxious to avoid a nuclear war as we are. War just doesn't make sense any more, for anybody. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But war doesn't make sense precisely because the weapons can kill an entire country -- right? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the prosecutor makes his point) Then don't you realize the Bomb gives us Peace not War?  And, if that's the case, I ask you again: Why do they want disarmament? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (despairing) Well, sir, like I said, for the same reasons we do.  I mean, all the experts say the most likely way for War to start nowadays is by an accident, or a mistake, or by some mentally unbalanced person -- (lets his voice trail off) MANDRAKE's discretion was unnecessary for it would never to GENERAL RIPPER that anyone would think him mentally un GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, Major. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gaining confidence) I was just going to say, as long as the weapons exist, sooner or later something's going to happen -- and that'll be it for both countries. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard the arguments.  Like Napoleon's quote, "There's one thing you can't do with a bayonet, and that's - sit on it." MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, sir.  And don't forget in a few years a lot of other countries will have the bomb.  What if they start something? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, Major.  You fascinate me. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, I remember an example that pointed out that if a system was safe on 99.99% of the days of the year, given average luck it would fail in thirty years. MAJOR MANDRAKE pauses to look for daylight.  RIPPER retur gaze, steadily. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still ask, why do they want disarmament? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, for the same reasons we do, sir. Don't you see? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Major, I don't.  They have no regard for human life.  They wouldn't care if they lost their whole country as long as they won. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, sir, that last remark doesn't exactly make all the sense in the world. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Major, you're talking like one of them! MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shook) Well, I'm not, sir.  Honestly, sir. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be offended, Major.  Our President holds the same views. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think he knows something about this, General Ripper? GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what I do think.  If they say they're for disarmament, I say anyone who says they're for disarmament is either a traitor or a damned fool. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, General, we're on our toes.  We haven't agreed to anything for years.  Inffact, a a lot of people say we never will. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if they suddenly opened up and gave us the inspection we want, we'd agree, wouldn't we? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they gave us what we think we need, yes, I guess we would. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you'd like to see that? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General, what's good enough for the President and all the experts he's got working on the thing, is good enough for me. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think we'd cheat? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.  I'm sure we wouldn't. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think they would cheat? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, sir.  I'm no expert on the subject, but I've read some pretty sharp ideas the big boys have.  Like, say, both countries agreeing to a million dollar reward and international protection for anyone who gives evidence of cheating to the inspectors. You can't hide those things without a lot of people knowing about it.  And if I were going to try and hide a few, I wouldn't want to depend on the fact that some poor slob isn't going to run and blab for a million bucks.  We're as smart as they are, and if they cheat, or even hold back information, we'd pull right out. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Major, I hate to say this, but I think you've been enemy indoctrinated, and you don't even know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air Force General "BUCK" SCHMUCK is speaking as the scene The huge, polished wood table is neatly spread with the r breakfast.  Eggs and bacon, melon, toast, silver thermos coffee, pastries, and glasses of ice water. GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In conclusion, I should like to observe that: One, our hopes for recalling the 843rd Bomb Wing are next to nothing.  Two, in about fifteen minutes the enemy will be making radar contacts with our planes.  Three, when they do, they will go absolutely Ape, and strike back with everything they've got.  Four, if prior to this we haven't done anything to suppress their retaliatory abilities, we will suffer virtual annihilation - in round numbers a hundred and fifty million killed.  Five, if we immediately launch an all-out missile attack on their bases, we stand an excellent chance of catching them off guard.  In that event, we will destroy the bulk of their retaliatory strength, prevail in the struggle, and suffer relatively modest and acceptable civilian casualties. He pauses and confidently looks around the table.  The PR stares at him inscrutably. GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I may, I'd like to illustrate my conclusion with a very brief story. (a squinty-eyed smile) I played guard on my high-school football team. I wasn't particularly big for the line, and my coach once told me something I've never for- gotten.  "Schmucko" he said - that was what they called me in those days - "Schmucko, always remember this.  The harder you hit the other fellow, the less you'll get hurt." (confidently checks each game) My recommendation is that we follow General Ripper's action to its logical end.  In other words, to hit the other fellow as hard as we can! No one says anything. ADMIRAL PERCY BULDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your estimate of casualties if we strike first? ADMIRAL PERCY BULDIKE is a model of the crisp, tough Navy man.  His lean, rugged features are lit by an obviou GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under those circumstances, oh, I'd say for us twenty to fifty million, depending on the breaks. For the enemy, something on the order of fifty million, if we stick to military targets. ADMIRAL PERCY BULDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are very casual about those figures, General Schmuck. GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all, Admiral Buldike.  Naturally, we all deeply regret such a sad loss - and let me be the first to say, I don't like the idea one bit that we'd be clobbering their women and children. But quit a few of their bases are very close to cities and towns, and to would be unavoidable. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, gentlemen, do you concur with General Schmuck? There is a nervous silence. GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister President, regretable as such a choice is, there is a quantitative difference between fifty and a hundred and fifty million of our dead. PRESIDENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck. Suppose I said to you I was going to cut away one quarter of your body - but not to worry because you'd still be three-quarters good, even if that three-quarters was rather monstrously deformed and helplessly crippled. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's a fair analogy, sir. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Admiral Buldike? The ADMIRAL squirms. ADMIRAL BULDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) I don't know...I just don't know. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Faceman? He hesitates like a poker player deciding whether to make GENERAL FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cooly) I'm afraid I have to flatly disagree with General Schmuck's proposal. I don't see how we can just cold-bloodedly hit them. Enter TURGIDSON, a senior Presidential aide.  All eyes tu TURGIDSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister President, I've got their Ambassador waiting upstairs. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good!  Any difficulty? TURGIDSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so, and he's having a fit about the squad of M.P.'s. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't be helped.  Have him brought down here right away. TURGIDSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exits) I'd better do it myself. PRESIDENT SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to let him in here - in the War Room? PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ambassador is here on my orders. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he'll hear everything we're saying.  And if he just looks out of that window, he'll see everything we're doing. (SCHMUCK refers to the War Room proper) PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scowls) That's the idea, General Schmuck. (turns to ZLAT, another senior aide) Zlat! ZLAT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir? The PRESIDENT looks up at a row of clocks which indicate time zones. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zlat, it's three-forty-five in the afternoon their time.  Put through a blitz priority telephone call to Premier Belch.  Try him at his office. ZLAT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates) We've never communicated with him on such an informal basis before.  It's possible he won't take the call. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they won't, Zlat, you'll tell whoever you get on the phone, a couple of dozen of their cities may be taken out within the next hour and a half.  He'll take the call. ZLAT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exits) Yes, sir. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankenstein! Another senior civilian aide. FRANKENSTEIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankenstein, I'll need a complete communications system set up between this room and the Premier. At least a dozen telephone circuits, radio, tele- printers - the works. FRANKENSTEIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think any of the maintenance or installation men are in at this hour of the morning sir. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sourly) Try, Frankenstein!  Try! FRANKENSTEIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exits, unhappily) I'll try, sir.  But I don't think it'll do any good. A phone rings. 36a  VARIOUS SHOTS - EVERYONE FREEZES ADMIRAL BULDIKE is closest to the phone. ADMIRAL BULDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?...Yes...Who is this?...I see ...Just a moment. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Is it him? ADMIRAL BULDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering phone) No, sir.  I believe it's personal for General Schmuck. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Personal? ADMIRAL BULDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  A Miss Milky way, I think she said. GENERAL SCHMUCK closes his eyes slowly, then assumes a ve businesslike look and takes the phone. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?...Yes, Miss Way...No, that's quite all right...Uh-huh...I'm a little tied up right now, Miss Way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36b  MISS MILKY WAY - FABULOUSLY SPRAWLED ACROSS HER BED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILKY WAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (southern accent) Buck, I know you're a General and everything, but if you don't learn to behave in a more gentlemanly way, I'm going to have to give up being a typist and take that movie offer... Well, what's so important (imitating him) Yes, Miss Way.  Yes, Miss Way.  Well, look now.  I'm going to take a bath and have breakfast and you come back here soon, you hear me, "Buck" Schmuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LT. LOTHAR ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bomb arming circuits are green, Major Kong. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Toejam, are you ready for Bim and Bam? LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready, Major. 38a  VARIOUS CU - INSERT INTERCUTS The actual arming is depicted as needing initial action b and bombardier, simultaneously. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primary arming switch. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primary arming switch. 38b  VARIOUS CU - INTERCUTS Both pilot and radio depress a switch guarded by a safety marked "l".  On the bombardier's control panel two greenl glow. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primary circuit is live. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primary trigger switch. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primary trigger switch. Pilot and radio again depress a switch marked TRIGGER.  A two green lights glow on bombardier's control panel.  He depresses his own trigger switch.  A third green light ap LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primary trigger circuit is live. Radio has now finished his part in the action.  He picks computer but does not use it, merely holding it as he lis like the rest of the crew, to the remainder of the arming cedure. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Release first safety. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First safety. The two operate their switches.  Two lights again glow on safety bank of panel. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second safety. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seond safety. The second pair of lihts glow on Safety bank.  Only one p now remains unlit. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fusing for ten thousand air burst. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check, ten thousand air burst. We see bombardier turn nob setting.  Needle creeps round ten thousand.  Bombardier presses in succession three con buttons marked: Electronic, Barometric, and Time. He waits while the appropriate three lights glow on. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Electronic, barometric, and time fusings all set for ten thousand air. Pauses, pushes back hair. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master safety. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Kong. Bombardier and pilot now press the last remaining switch, marked "MASTER SAFETY". The two remaining lights on Safety panel glow, and bombar glances quickly at the banked rows of glowing lights. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primary bomb is live. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Lothat, that does it.  Master safety on now until bomb run. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master safety on. They put the master safety switches up, and on the bombar panel we see the two final lights go off.

dialogues.speaker: MACHINE GUN POSITION
dialogues.text: Fifty yards outside wire perimeter fence, a first-sergean two privates are hunched over a .30 calibre air-cooled ma gun. 41a  THEY SEE DOWN ROAD About three hundred yards away, a jeep and three troop tr cautiously approaching. PRIVATE STIFFSOCKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we know they're saboteurs? SERGEANT BLUNT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (peering through binoculars) How do you know they're not? PRIVATE TUNG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Charlie.  You heard what the General said - two hundred yards. The vehicles continue closer. SERGEANT BLUNT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swinging binoculars) There's eight more trucks on the North road! We see the eight trucks about two miles away. PRIVATE STIFFSOCKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose they must be subversives or saboteurs.  Why else would they suddenly be coming at four in the morning? PRIVATE TUNG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natch. 41b  OTHER CUTS AROUND BASE PERIMETER of base defense teams watching over their weapons. 41c  VARIOUS CUTS - ACTION SEQUENCE SERGEANT BLUNT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Okay, Stiffsocks, open up. The machine gun fires three longish blasts which spray ac the path of the land jeep.  It swerves into a ditch and t over. The convoy stops and we see troops leap out of the trucks persing into the fields on each side of the road.  Many a partly dressed. Two men drag the injured from the overturned jeep. 41d  VARIOUS CUTS - TROOPS WAITING The scattered firing gradually stops.  All we hear are in and the distant sound of the second truck convoy. A loudspeaker suddenly clicks on in the distance. COLONEL "BAT" GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudspeaker) This is Colonel "Bat" Guano of the 701st Special Service Battalion.  Why are you men firing on us? Silence. PRIVATE STIFFSOCKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we answer? SERGEANT BLUNT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep down, you dope, and open up on the first one who shows his head. COLONEL "BAT" GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Colonel Guano.  We are on a mission from the President.  We want to enter the base and speak to General Ripper. Silence. PRIVATE TUNG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother, that's a beauty.  A special mission from the President. SERGEANT BLUNT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say one thing.  You've got to give the enemy credit for organization and planning. 41e  VARIOUS CUTS Two hundred yeards away a skirmishing party of a dozen or widely spaced about thirty yeards apart, rises out of the and begins to work its way forward. PRIVATE STIFFSOCKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) They've got guts too. The machine gun fires.  Three men are hit immediately, th dive for cover. The firing stops.  Ten seconds of silence. COLONEL "BAT" GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Colonel Guano.  Men, you are firing on your own troops.  Unless you surrender within sixty seconds, I am under orders to return your fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is hunched over his master search radarscope.  See coastl coming at top of tube. LT. BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should be crossing the coast in about six minutes. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Binky.  Can you see Bromdingna Island yet? LT. BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concentrated on scope) I don't think so. He adjusts the brilliance of the radarscope. 43a  RADARSCOPE We see two flashes of light. 43b  VARIOUS CUTS - ACTION SEQUENCE LT. QUIFFER (D.S.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missiles!  Sixty miles off, heading in fast.  Steady track, they look like beam riders. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger, keep calling them. (to co-pilot) Knock off auto-pilot, Ace. The co-pilot reaches forward and flips two switches. CAPTAIN "ACE" ANGST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Auto-pilot off, King. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock ECM onto master search radar. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flipping switches) ECM locked to master search radar. He looks at the large ECM (Electronic-Counter-Measures) c panel.  It is an electronic marvel with all the appropria lights, gauges, and oscillographs.  He speaks to himself. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to ECM) You big, beautiful brain, you better start thinking. He gives the panel a pat. CAPTAIN ANGST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you suppose they were fired from? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quentin, have you picked up any aircraft? LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the missiles. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must have been fired from Bromdingna - probably one of their new Vampire - 202's. They've got a range well over a hundred miles. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-five.  Still coming straight and fast. Twelve o' clock. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speed? LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between Mach 3 and 4. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call them every five miles. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-five, still straight. 43c  VARIOUS CUTS TO CREW during sequence, as they sweat it out. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty!  Twelve o' clock and straight. 43d  VARIOUS CUTS TO RADARSCOPE tracking the missiles. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty!  Twelve o' clock. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maximum ECM! The bombadier flips six switches.  Various indicators lig LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maximum ECM. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen!  Twelve o' clock. While D.S.O. watches it approach. LT. QUIFFER
Pilot sharply banks the huge jet.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: 44a  INT. B-90 Plane still in steep, diving bank. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four miles, three...they're turning in on us!  They're coming in! The pilot throws the plane in a violent S-ing, corkscrewi There is a deafening EXPLOSION in the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: DAWN
dialogues.text: Limousine and jeeps are scattered near the entrance which guarded by six M.P.'s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hysterical) Mister President, I demand to be taken back to my embassy at once. The AMBASSADOR is clad in striped pyjamas and black, velv collared coat. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please be calm, Ambassador De Sade. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) You will not get away with this vicious attack on our peace-loving people. The AMBASSADOR yammers away under the PRESIDENT's speech. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waffel! WAFFEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir! PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please see how they're getting along on the call to Premier Belch. WAFFEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exits) Yes, sir. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Premier Belch will not be fooled by this fantastic lie. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubling his fists) Mister President, are you going to let this stooge talk to you like this? The PRESIDENT steps in front of the AMBASSADOR to protect PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Schmuck! Ambassador De Sade is here as my guest.  He is to be treated with the proper respect. GENERAL SCHMUCK skulks off, scowling. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you say so, sir. The AMBASSADOR was obviously afraid SCHMUCK was going to AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns after SCHMUCK) War-mongering bully!  Don't think you're going to intimidate me! PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Mister Ambassador!  But you must treat General "Buck" Schmuck with the respect due him. The AMBASSADOR slumps down in his chair, miserably. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pathetically) Can I have a glass of water? PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly - how about some breakfast? AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs interestedly) Possibly some coffee? PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing) Moffo! MOFFO, a clean-cut aide. MOFFO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steps forward) Would you like anything else with it, Mister Ambassador? AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unhappily) I reall shouldn't.  I'll ruin my diet. MOFFO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, surely you can break your diet a little today, sir. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs, sourly) All right - I'd like orange juice, three fried eggs turned over, bacon, toast, coffee, and some sweet rolls. MOFFO and pencil catching up. MOFFO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have it brought right down. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grudgingly) Thank you.  Oh - and can you bring me a pack of AMBASSADOR DE SADE (cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cigarettes - any filtered brand? Exit, MOFFO. ADMIRAL BULDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds out a pack) Here, have one of mine. The AMBASSADOR takes a cigarette.  ADMIRAL BULDIKE lights with his Ronson. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exhaling) Thank you, Admiral. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
