dialogues.text: Now, Mister Ambassador.  In a very few moments we should have Premier Belch on the phone.  I intend to tell him exactly what has happened.  I merely want you to authenticate certain facts for him. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up suspiciously) The food - you wouldn't put - anything in it, would you? PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have your word, Mister President? PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savagely, from across the room) We don't operate like you KGB boys. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock it off will you, General? (to CRUDLEY, an aide) Crudley, find out what's holding up that call! Exit CRUDLEY. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you trying to reach him? PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his office in the Capitol. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's not there, try... (thinks) 87 - 43 - 56. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get that, Kulnick? KULNICK nods and exits. During the next speech, AMBASSADOR DE SADE sidles up to t plate-glass window opening out to the War Room.  As he ta sneaks out a Minox camera, and takes a picture. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His office won't have that number.  It's a very special phone number, and the Premier can't trust his secretary not to tell his wife. GENERAL SCHMUCK has see him take the photograph and strik a cat, grabbing for the camera. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grappling for camera) Okay, pal - I'll take that! The both fumble for the tiny camera. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you dare touch me!  What the devil do you think you're doing? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I caught you red-handed, Mister Ambassador. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give that back to me. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flourishing camera) What do you think of this, Mister President? (triumphant) I told you we shouldn't let him in here. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the meaning of this? AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry.  Sub-miniature photography is my hobby.  It's amazing what excellent en- largements you can make from the negative. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) I'll hold this, if you don't mind.  You can have it back when you leave.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A thin wisp of smoke trails from inside port pod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All dialogue comes rapid-fire, amidst coughing, wiping ey MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flipping switches) Shutting down three and four. CAPTAIN ANGST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire systems operating on three and four. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking in scope) Radar okay.  No more missiles. CAPTAIN ANGST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flipping switches) Everyone on emergency oxygen. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flipping switches) All right...we're still flying.  I'm taking her down to the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me revs for maximum speed at sea level. LT. BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what that'll do to our fuel consumption. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't help it.  What's the wind like? LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't be bad.  Might even help.  But my guess is we're going to have to paddle our way back. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll worry about that later.  Okay, I'll take damage reports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The popping of small arms fire outside.  RIPPER still has MANDRAKE at the mercy of his .45. Stray bursts of small arms fire have smashed the windows, occasionally a few shots tear up the wall.  Both men are GENERAL RIPPER is philosophically drunk and very sentimen GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting on the floor) You know, when I was a kid, I used to read a lot.  I loved to read.  One of my favorites was the "Jungle Book" by Kipling.  Did you ever read it, Major? MAJOR MANDRAKE lies flat on the floor and trembles with f MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. A rifle shot splatters the window again.  MANDRAKE flinch GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should.  In particular, read the story of the little mongoose, called Riki-tiki-tavi, because of the noise he made.  He was taken in as a house pet.  In the garden of the house lived a couple of cobras, and pretty soon the mongoose kills the male cobra because he's laying for the man of the house. MAJOR MANDRAKE manages a brave but idiotic smile. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the female cobra is left, and she's got a clutch of eggs which will hatch a dozen young cobras.  She decides Riki has to go. She says so, and she means it.  The little mongoose weighs up the odds.  He can handle the cobra if she comes after him.  He just has to keep his eyes open and be ready for her at any time.  But once the eggs hatch and the young cobras become dangerous - he's gone.  He can't handle that many at once. A longish burst of automatic fire rakes across the wall, height, dropping three framed 8 x 10 photographs of Air F Generals. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he waits his chance, and when the female cobra is causing mischief somewhere else, he breaks the eggs.  He has to kill the young cobras since it's just a matter of time before they kill him.  So he acts and he lives. He is safe, the people in the house are safe. They can live their lives in peace. GENERAL RIPPER is glassy-eyed with emotion.  MAJOR MANDRA stupidly. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major, pour two more drinks, please. MAJOR MANDRAKE creeps to the bar. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if MANDRAKE were somehow derelict in his duty) Major, those are my boys out there dying. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making drinks) Yes, sir.  Why don't you stop the fighting, sir? GENERAL RIPPER looks at his watch and begins to nod.  He nodding for about thirty seconds. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good officer, Major Mandrake.  You think of your men first. MAJOR MANDRAKE crawls over with the drinks. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising glass, moodily) To peace on earth, Major. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbles) Peace on earth. They drink.  RIPPER starts nodding again. RIPPER picks up the p.a. mike and fumbles for the switch. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is General Ripper speaking.  There has been an unfortunate mistake.  You have been fighting our own troops.  They are not saboteurs.  You will cease fire immediately. I repeat, cease fire imediately.  Good work, men.  I'm proud of you. Shuts off button. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General, now that you've done that, I beg you to recall the Wing. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major, I happen to believe in a life after this one, so I believe I will have to answer for what I have done.  I think I can. They touch glasses and drink. GENERAL RIPPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (choked with pride) Major, go out there and stop the fighting. MAJOR MANDRAKE exits, closing the door behind him. 51a  CU - GENERAL RIPPER Tears roll down his gallantly insane face.  He picks up h automatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A telephone is placed on the conference table. ZLAT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking in a strange foreign language) He covers the mouthpiece. ZLAT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) They've got Premier Belch on the line. He's at that other number. (makes an inappropriately suggestive hint) but his interpreter is with him.  You'll actually talk to him, and he'll shoot a simultaneous translation from you to the Premier, and vice vrsa. The PRESIDENT takes a deep breath, sits down, and takes t He thinks for a moment, forces a relaxes look, and speaks PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...Hello...Premier Belch...How are you? ...This is Merkin...Yes, Merkin Muffley. How are you?...Merkin Muffley...Sure it is ...Just a second, will you hold on a second? PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't believe me. (hands phone) Please don't tell him more than that. DE SADE nods worriedly. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (we hear a strange foreign language understanding the name Merkin Muffley) I told him the call was genuine. DE SADE hands the phone back. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?...Yes...Uh-huh...certainly I understand ...Oh someone tried it on you once before... Look, Belch, I'll tell you why I called... Hello...Hello...Can you hear me?...Say, could they turn the music down a little?...Oh, well, could they stop playing?...Oh, good, I thought we lost the connection there for a minute... yes, I hear you very clearly...Well, look... (clears throat) You know how we've always talked about the possibility of something going wrong?...With the H-bomb...uh-huh...that's right...Well, it happened...Hello?...Can you still hear me?... What?...Not missiles - planes...that's right... B-90's...That's right...Thirty-four of them... In about an hour and a half...uh-huh...Uh-huh ...Uh-huh...Well, how do you think I feel about it?...I know that...Uh-huh...Uh-huh...Well, why do you think I'm calling you?...to work some- thing out on this disarmament thing...Uh-huh... Sure, but you haven't been reasonable...Uh-huh... Uh-huh...Look Belch...Look, we're wasting time... Uh-huh...a base commander...We're not sure... Well, we think he's gone psycho...Had a mental breakdown...We're trying to do that...We're doing that right now...Well, we've got our fingers crosses...we're hoping...We're trying that too... Uh-huh...Uh-huh...Uh-huh...That's not fair for you to say...We're doing everything we possibly can ...Certainly...Sure I can imagine...Uh-huh... PRESIDENT MUFFLEY (cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh...Uh-huh...Look, there's something else.  We want to give your Air Staff a complete rundown on the targets, flight plans, and defensive systems of the planes ...No, it's on the level...Sure I hate to do a thing like that, but at this point it's got to be a case of one hand scratches the other...co-operate...Right now...Who should they call?...The People's Central Air Defense Headquarters?...Where?...In Karnak?...Right... You'll call them first...Uh-huh...Do you happen to have the phone number?...Just ask Karnak information?... (he gestures to GENERAL SCHMUCK who exits the room) What's that?...Yes, I'm listening...Uh-huh... Uh-huh...a hundred thousand megatons...Cobalt- Thorium-G casing?...What's that for?...Uh-huh ...Uh-huh...Irrevocable and automatic?...Uh- huh...Why didn't you let us know?...Sure I know the Party Congress is next week...Certainly I understand..but what are we supposed to do about it now?...Right...Okay, well, how long will it take for you to get back to your office?...Right, well call me back as soon as you do...BEdlock 3- 3333, extension, 2497...If you forget, just ask for me...Right...Bye-bye. Hangs up phone. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to AMBASSADOR DE SADE) The Premier says that've got a Doomsday Machine that can kill all human life on earth- is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a dozen Air Force language experts are communicatin radio, giving the information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes are directed to AMBASSADOR DE SADE. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) It was to have been announced at the party congress next week.  I did not know the fools would make it operational until then. DE SADE is plainly shaken and swallows some iced water. GENERAL FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Well, what the hell is a Doomsday Machine? AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pale) May I have a cigarette? GENERAL FACEMAN gives him a cigarette and lights it, as h continues. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Well, it's ridiculously simple, really. As you all know, the intense, lethal radio- activity from a so-called normal nuclear device dissipates itself at a certain rate. Something like __________after the first hours, ___________after twenty-four hours, until at the end of a week, it's just________ of its lethal dose. He takes a deep drag on the cigarette, holds it, and exha AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it has been explained to me that, if you add a thick Cobalt-Thorium-G jacket to a nuclear device, the radio- activity resulting from such a nuclear explosion will retain its lethal power for a hundred years. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Our scientists calculated that the detonation of fifty of our biggest nuclear devices, jacketed in Cobalt-Thorium-G would enshroud the earth in a hundred years of lethal radio- activity from which no human life could escape. In ten months the Earth would be as dead as the Moon. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is this...thing? AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is buried somewhere in the Grudd Mountains. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) Do you mean to say you'd set it off in your own country? AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally.  It would kill us just as surely even if we set it off in your country.  But this way we know it's safe, and we don't have the problem of delivering it. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister President, I can't buy this malarkey; they wouldn't set the damn thing off.  Why should they? AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're absolutely right.  We wouldn't.  No sane nation ever would.  That's why it was designed to trigger itself automatically. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then all you have to do is untrigger it. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, but if we were able to untrigger it, that would be defeating its purpose.  All our enemies would have to do, would be to warn us in advance that they were going to violate one of our unalterable triggering conditions. We would bluff, naturally, but in the end we would be insane not to untrigger it. Now we can say: There is no point trying to intimidate us, we don't control the Doomsday Machine. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scornfully) Mister Ambassador, what on earth possessed your country to build this weapon? AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, economic reasons.  It was cheap.  The entire project cost just a fraction of what we spent in a single year on our various space and missile programs. It also seemed ideal in most other respects. It was terrifying, convincing, automatic, and extremely simple to understand. He puffs the cigarette. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, any of our leaders opposed it on the grounds: Yes, all well and good, but what happens if it has to be used? He sighs. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, finally, one factor tipped the scales. We received information from a very re- liable source that your country was going to build one. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's preposterous!  We have no such program! AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The source was...shall we say, completely reliable. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The report is entirely untrue.  I can assure you of that. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it, Mister President.  I've been warning for years that we're still riddled with traitors. While the following dialogue continues, MOFFO enters with large tray of food.  As unobtrusively as possible, he pla on the conference table, and AMBASSADOR DE SADE pulls up with gusto. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funkel! A thin-faced, studious man steps forward. FUNKEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have anything like this in the works? FUNKEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd heard some talk, but I wouldn't like to say for sure, Mister President. PRESIDENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What??? Funkel, you're suppose to be my scientific advisor!  Don't you know? FUNKEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps Didley, in Weapons Evaluation might know. DIDLEY, a short, crew-cut, studious chap in his early for smoking a pipe. DIDLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling manfully) I'm afraid not, sir.  But possibly Von Klutz in Research and Development? VON KLUTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) I haven't heard of it, sir! AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you gentlemen would like to check with the source? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you'll tell us his name??? AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a he, General.  It was an article in the "Times" about a year and a half ago. VARIOUS AD LIBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? The "Times"?? I always knew it had subversive tendencies. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get much of our most dependable information from the "Times".  As I recall the article said a Doctor Otto Strangelove, at the Bland Corporation, was working on the idea.  Naturally, you could not expect us to believe he would be doing such a thing as a hobby! There is a soft knock, and the door opens without waiting reply. MAJOR NONCE, one of GENERAL SCHMUCK's Air Force aides, en GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Nonce.  What is it? MAJOR NONCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (factually) Gentlemen, we have just received word that the base at Burpelson has surrendered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene opens as if on a still photograph.  MAJOR MANDR stands motionless and expressionless in the bullet-splatt

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA
dialogues.text: moves and reveals GENERAL RIPPER grotesquely sprawled, fa on the floor behind his desk, the .45 nearby. MANDRAKE kneels next to RIPPER and confirms he is dead. MANDRAKE rises and leans on the desk. He sees a wallet of photographs neatly laid out, obviousl mother and father. Examining the clutter on RIPPER's desk, he notices a rule legal-size tablet.  There are a number of boxes, heavily

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA
dialogues.text: moves in closer to tablet.  We see a repetition of the ph "Peace on Earth."  It is scribbled about eight times. 56a  COLONEL "BAT" GUANO - ENTERS - PYJAMA TOP AND BATTLE A tough, crew-cut, youngish (35) Battalion commander.  Ca slung over his shoulder, helmet hanging from carbine, he into the office standing for a moment, hands on hips, sur the scene.  MAJOR MANDRAKE is seated at the desk, staring space and apparently babbling utter nonsense. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weirdly) Peace On Earth...Peace On Earth... Peace On Earth... He doesn't acknowledge COLONEL "BAT" GUANO's presence.  C stares at him suspiciously. COLONEL "BAT" GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Major?...Major?  I'm Colonel "Bat" Guano, 701 Battalion. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pinching the bridge of his nose and grimacing) Come in...come in... Peace On Earth... Peace On Earth...yes... COLONEL "BAT" GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you saying that phrase over and over again? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that just might be it!  Although it could be Riki-Tiki-Tavi. COLONEL "BAT" GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scowls, suspiciously) What are you talking about, Major? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to babble) The three-letter code group.  Or maybe some combination of the three letters. P...O...E, or P...E...O, or E...O...P... let's see, there would be six possible combinations. COLONEL "BAT" GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Get a grip on yourself, Major! MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might still be worth trying Riki-Tiki- Tavi.  R...T...T...There's only three combinations of -- T...T...R, or T...R...T... COLONEL GUANO gives MAJOR MANDRAKE an open-handed whack i face!  MANDRAKE lets out a howl of pain. COLONEL "BAT" GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, snap out of it, fella! MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding face) Who the hell do you think you are, sir??? COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (John Wayne) I did that for your own good, fella.  Now I'm not going to pull rank on you.  When this is over, I'll be happy to step outside with you and settle this thing.  Right now my orders are to locate General Ripper and put him on the phone with the President. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can't do that because he's dead. He points to the floor behind the desk.  COLONEL GUANO st forward and looks at the body.  He kneels and examines th suspiciously. COLONEL GUANO moves carefully to the other side of the de unslings his carbine, and covers MAJOR MANDRAKE. COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any witnesses, Major? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened, Major?  Some kind of private beef between the two of you? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Look, I didn't shoot him! COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have to leave that up to the C.I.D. boys, won't we, Major? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Colonel.  I've got to talk to somebody at Air Command. COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Major.  Your rights will be fully protected. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, don't you know what's going on? COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I do.  There was some kind of mutiny on the base, and you killed General Ripper. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, General Ripper went off his rocker and ordered the 843rd Bomb Wing to attack with H-bombs. COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) You must think I'm an awful sap, Major. (MAJOR MANDRAKE starts to move) Just sit down, fella, and keep your hands on the desk! MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't they tell you? COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking head) They told me, Major.  And I didn't hear anything about any atomic attack. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talks slowly and simple) Look, Colonel.  You keep me covered, but let me just pick up this red telephone that connects to Air Command headquarters. Okay?...I won't play any tricks on you... Okay? COLONEL GUANO can't think of any good reason not to. COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, fella.  But just move slow and don't do anything that might surprise me. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure...sure, Colonel.  Now look, I'm picking up the phone...nice and slow.  Right?...Hello? ...Hello? (he clicks the receiver) Hello?...Hello?...Gee, it must be edad. Probably the lines were hit during the fighting. COLONEL GUANO watches him like a hawk. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look, I'm picking up this ordinary telephone.  See?...Hello?...Hello?... Nuts, the lines must still be disconnected. (he smiles idiotically) The General had us disconnect... (he lets his voice trail off when he sees RUDLEY's weird look of hatred and suspicion) MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately) Look, Colonel.  Maybe it's too late. Maybe they've sent Air Command in already.  But we've got to try to con- tact somebody. COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On your feet, fella.  I've got to get outside and see how my men are. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Colonel.  But look, there's a pay phone just outside in the hall.  Maybe that works, huh?  Maybe it'll work?  What do you think? COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've wasted enough of my time, fella. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps his fingers) Wait a minute.  The President!!  That's it! The President!!! COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) What about the President? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wanted to talk to General Ripper, didn't he? COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the wheel turns slowly) So what? MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm General Ripper's Executive officer. He'll want to talk to me. COLONEL GUANO's mind is not prepared for this new twist. his head to one side and studies MANDRAKE. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you see?  He'll want to talk to me! And if he finds out that you wouldn't let MAJOR MANDRAKE (Cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: him talk to me...Well, I'd say you'd be in for a pretty severe reprimand, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56b  PHONE BOOTH IN HALL - MANDRAKE AND GUANO MAJOR MANDRAKE is seated in the booth, illuminated by a b flourescent overhead, his hand on the half-closed door. GUANO leans against the door jamb, listening.  His carbin down, but his grip indicates he isn't taking any chances. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a lot of change spread out in front of him) Operator, this is Major Mandrake at Burpelson Air Force Base.  I would like to place an emergency call to Merkin Muffley at the Capitol.  That's right, the President ...Try the War Room. He smiles, hopefully, at COLONEL GUANO's sinister face. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, operator, the President... Operator, how much will that be for the first three minutes?...Two dollars and twenty-five cents? He quickly counts his change and sees it's not enough.  H fumbling through his pockets.  No more change. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, operator, can you make this a collect call?  That's right, Major Mandrake from Burpelson...They aren't allowed to?...Tell them it's terrifically important...Just a second... He opens the door and addresses COLONEL GUANO. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, they aren't allowed to accept any collect long-distance calls.  The operator MAJOR MANDRAKE (Cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: says it's policy.  I need fifty-five cents. COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) I wouldn't carry loose change going into combat. MAJOR MANDRAKE looks around desperately.  A Coke machine stands next to the phone booth. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Operator...How much would the call be station-to-station?...Thirty-five cents cheaper?...I'd still be short twenty cents ...Just a second, operator... (covers mouthpiece) Colonel, shoot the lock off the Coke machine. (he points) There's bound to be enough change in there. COLONEL GUANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) That's government property, Major. MAJOR MANDRAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, remember, a reprimand from the President can be pretty serious to a career officer...Just a second, operator, I know I have it somewhere. COLONEL GUANO apologetically fires a shot into the coin b Coins spill on the floor in profusion, as well as a strea in the COLONEL's sputtering face.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: As the "Leper Colony" presses on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enter, GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with quiet majesty) Mister President, Gentlemen, we are saved. AD LIBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping) What? Wow! You mean that was it? The old know-how. GENERAL SCHMUCK basks in the grandeur of the moment. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a variation of "Peace on Earth" - OPE to be exact. AD LIBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping) Can you beat that? Peace on Earth. Brother! The human mind sure is amazing. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you received acknowledgements from every plane? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're coming in now. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long will it take to receive them all? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not certain, Mister President.  The boys in CONCOM do the pencil work. The tone of GENERAL SCHMUCK's remark is as if to say: I a your errand boy. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Schmuck, if you don't know the answer, please find out! GENERAL SCHMUCK decides against a head-on collision. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe it will be just a few minutes, at the most. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many planes did we lose? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not certain, Mister President.  But I believe it was four. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Faceman, what was the name of the officer who called me from Burpelson? GENERAL FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't speak to him, sir.  But Colonel "Bat" Guano was in command of the Special Service battalion, so I would imagine he did. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want him upped to Brigadier General, and recomended for the D.S.C. GENERAL FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming) Yes, sir. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about the rest of you, Gentlemen, but I'm going to get down on my knees and say a short prayer of thanks. AMBASSADOR DE SADE stands with a flourish of contempt, pu away his breakfast tray. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but I'm afraid I have many more urgent things to attend to.  I should appreciate it if you would delay your pious moment long enough for me to say something. His tone of voice is loaded with contempt, challenge, and PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (darkly) Yes? AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow me to assure you that my government will not be satisfied with a polite note of regret for this shocking example of aggression against our peace-loving people. THE PRESIDENT has just about had it with De Sade and is s by the rudeness of his tone. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn you, de Sade!  You know as well as I do that this was the act of a mentally sick man - a single individual, whose crack-up can probably be traced to the strains and tensions caused by your country. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (haughtily) It is very convenient to place all the blame on a dead man. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fiercely) How dare you talk to me in this manner? AMBASSADOR DE SADE scornfully replies with silence. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (boiling with indignation) This dreadful accident could never have happened if your government hadn't cynically and hypocritic- ally blocked every proposal we made for disarmament or arms control!! AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waspishly) Bah!  All you wanted to do was spy in our country! PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wrathfully) That's nonsense, and you know it! AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acrimoniously) I know nothing of the sort! PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Surely, you don't expect us to destroy our weapons without being able to verify that you are doing the same? AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And surely you don't expect us to let you spy in our country before you destroy your weapons. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savagely) Don't you realize that despite your incredible distrust and suspicion, that in fact, you place a far greater trust in us than inspection would require?  You trust us not to cause a war accidentally - and, of course, we are obliged to place the same trust in you. The PRESIDENT walks close to DE SADE, eyes flashing. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raging) Is there a single phase of human activity that is free from the idiotic mischance?  How often do we read of banks adding three zeros to a hundred dollar deposit?  Or the Postal Department engraving a stamp with the wrong amount?  Or an operation performed on the wrong patient? The PRESIDENT continues with mounting fury. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting rabidly) The bomb may deter a rational leader from choosing deliberate war, but it cannot deter a madman, or a short-circuit, or an error in judgment.  And since neither of us can reduce the chances for the idiotic mischance to zero, it simply becomes a question of when? ZLAT has been holding the phone. ZLAT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister President, I think Premier Belch is coming back on the line.  He's back in his office.

dialogues.speaker: CREW
dialogues.text: Low-level terrain features flashing by. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's have a rundown on the damage, Lothar? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bombardier) Everything still checks out okay. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Binky? LT. BINKY BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (navigator) Okay, Major. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check.  Quentin? LT. QUENTIN QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (peevishly) Look, I haven't really been able to check - I'm shot. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you hit bad? LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got it in the thigh. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Toejam, why don't you help him? The radio man, LIEUTENANT TERRY TOEJAM, is sitting right the wounded D.S.O. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I should check out the damage first. My gear is busted up pretty bad. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Toejam's going to help you in a minute.  Can you check your ECM? LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't he help me now?  He's sitting two feet away from me! MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Quentin, isn't that pretty selfish, putting yourself ahead of the mission? LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm shot - it hurts. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) Lieutenant Quiffer, we're all sorry you were hit, and we'll help you stick it together as soon as we get squared away. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, can't someone help me? CAPTAIN ANGST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unsympathetically) King, I'm not busy. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Captain Angst is coming back to help you. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Kong, I'm still trying to unravel the leads, but it looks hopeless.  All radio gear is kaput, including the CRM-114.  I guess we're on our own. 60a  CU - CRM-114 - IT IS SMASHED AND TWISTED AND CHARRED 60b  CU - MAJOR KONG MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then, here's the situation. With our ECM and staying on the deck, they shouldn't be able to track us on radar. We should make it to the primary and take out the missile base.  We're burning up alot of fuel at this altitude, and we may not make it back to a useable base.  But I think there's an excellent chance to bail out over neutral territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PRESIDENT speaks with the confidence of a salesman af has closed a deal.  The Ambassador is still there. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?...Belch?...I just wanted to let you know everything's all right...Uh-huh... Certainly...We broke the code...Uh-huh... Yes, they've all acknowledged the recall... Uh-huh...Thirty...Originally?...there were thirty-four...That's right - we figure four shot down...Are you sure of that?... I see...Will you hold it for a second. The PRESIDENT covers the phone and fixes a withering look GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Schmuck, are you positive of your figures? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally I am, sir. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says they've only shot down three planes. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you choose to take his word over mine --- PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, he's there, and you're here. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nettled) Mister President, there were thirty-four aircraft involved.  Thirty acknowledged the recall.  That makes four shot down. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to phone) Hello, are you still there?...Uh-huh...I'll be right back.  We're still working this thing out. Covering the phone, the PRESIDENT directs himself again t SCHMUCK. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know they were shot down, Buck? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, just common sense, sir.  Thirty from thirty-four equals four, or my name's not "Buck" Schmuck! The PRESIDENT dolefully digests GENERAL SCHMUCK's logic. There is a low, squawking sound from the telephone. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?...Yes...What?...Uh-huh...You're absolutely certain? (sighs) Hold it a second, will you? (covers phone) He says they've just received a report of a single, low-flying B-90 apparently still continuing on an attack mission, to what they assume would be a missile complex at a place called Laputa. AD LIBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Impossible! Ridiculous! During the last part of the PRESIDENT's speech, another p several times.  TURGIDSON picked it up and talked in hush TURGIDSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) General Schmuck, it's Miss Milky Way again. She insists on speaking to you. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord, Turgidson!  I can't talk to her now. TURGIDSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her you were busy, General Schmuck, but she got rather huffy. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily) Turgidson, tell her I'll call her back in a few minutes. ADMIRAL BULDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (replaces phone) Mister President, the latest radar contacts indicate the enemy are still building up over the Arctic pack.  We estimate five-hundred- plus aircraft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking out over nose of the plane.  Trees, a road, a clu houses, a small town, all flash by. 63a  VARIOUS CUTS AND INSERTS The D.S.O. is bandaged up and apparently functioning agai LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Kong, I have two blips - must be fighters. See insert of radarscope. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at radarscope again) Fighters closing fast - range fifty miles. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must have made a visual contact. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be Mach two-five stuff.  Altitude fifteen thousand. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't touch us at this height. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're moving apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enter GENERAL SCHMUCK, shaking his head morosely. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beginning to look like someone's made somewhat of an error, sir. The PRESIDENT closes his eyes and breathes heavily. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Yes? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, it looks like one aircraft, the "Leper Colony", failed to receive the recall. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you tried the recall again? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  We're still sending it.  But it's a funny thing we don't seem to be able to make any contact with the aircraft at all. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the target. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the Premier doped it out pretty well. Its primary is their missile base at Laputa. The PRESIDENT slumps into a chair. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mournfully) Is there any chance a single aircraft can penetrate the entire enemy Air Defense, when its course and target are known? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at the AMBASSADOR) If I can speak freely, sir -- look, these guys talk big, but frankly, we think they're short of know-how.  You can't just take a bunch of ignorant peasants and expect them to understand a machine like one of our boys, and I don't mean that as an insult, Mister Ambassador.  Hell, we all know what kind of guts your people have.  Why just look how many millions of 'em those Nazis (pronounced NAZZEES) killed and, hell, they still wouldn't quit. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General, stick to the point, please. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making diving aircraft hands) Well, sir, if the A/C's a really good man, I mean really sharp, why he can barrel that plane along so low - well you just have to see it some time.  A real big plane, like a Sting Ray, zig-zagging in, its jet exhaust frying chickens in the barnyard --- (almost feverish with excitement) Has he a chance?.....Hell, yes!  He has one hell of a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're starting down, King.  Looks like LT. QUIFFER (Cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: they're going to cross in port and starboard. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they come down low enough to make a firing pass, they'll never be able to pull up in time. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they mean business. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on, boys. He starts a violent series of S-ing and zig-zagging.

dialogues.speaker: TWO ENEMY "KILLERSHARK" ALL-WEATHER FIGHTERS
dialogues.text: maneuver in a steep dive, trying to hang on to their slow more maneuverable quarry. 67a  REAR SHOT - LOW LEVEL - B-90 - S-ING AND ZIG-ZAGGING at tree-top height, over the moonlit countryside. 67b  VARIOUS INTERCUTS - AIRCRAFT MANEUVERING 67c  ENEMY FIGHTERS Each fires a salvo of rockets from above, a bad angle for seeking missiles. 67d  B-90 TAKING EVASIVE ACTION The rockets pass over and under, exploding with bright fl they hit the ground. 67e  ONE ROCKET is exploded by its proximity fuse about nine feet from th just behind the crew section. 67f  INT. B-90 - VARIOUS QUICK CUTS Flash, black smoke, choking coughs. 67g  ENEMY FIGHTERS Make no attempt to pull out of their dives and continue t apparently trying to ram the bomber.  They swoop down and port and starboard like two hawks. 67h  B-90 wildly maneuvers and manages narrowly to evade both fight unable to pull up, explode against the ground in bright b flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smoke has cleared to a greyish mist.  A jagged hole a four feet at its widest has been blasted out of the rear crew section. 68a  MAJOR KONG is wounded in the back.  His vision clouds with pain as h to maintain consciousness. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ace, you better take it.  All fire switches... on. He turns to the co-pilot. 68b  CO-PILOT "ACE" ANGST IS DEAD though no wound is apparent. 68c  MAJOR KONG spasmodically takes deep breaths.  Summoning up all his n concentration, he leans forward and flips the "fire" swit the same time flying the plane and intermittently glancin moonlit terrain flashing under the nose of the big plane. 68d  VARIOUS CUTS MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody come up here quick, I'm hit. The seating arrangement in the B-90 is such that the uppe places the D.S.O. and the radio man about ten feet behind and co-pilot, facing the tail of the plane. The bombardier and the navigator sit facing forward on a and lower level. Naturally, Major Kong expects help from the nearest crew- member, the D.S.O. or the radio man. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on!  Hurry up. He twists himself painfully to look over his shoulder. 68e  TWO SHOT - LT. QUIFFER AND LT. TOEJAM The D.S.O. studiously attends to his work.  The radio, Li TERRY TOEJAM, sits cross-legged, examining his ankle. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without turning around) Sorry, King.  My leg's stiff as a board. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to radio man) Hey, Terry, I'm hit. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (minutely studying a slight ankle wound) So am I. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I think I'm hit bad. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still absorbed in his ankle) Where'd they get you? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn you, Lieutenant Toejam!  Lothar! LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Major. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lothar, get up here fast, and bring your First- Aid kit!  I'm hit kinda bad, I think. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't "Ace" help you? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bit his jugular vein.  Now will you shut up and get up here??? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure!  Sure, I'm on my way. While the colored bombardier works his way up the ladder, KONG takes a long and uncomprehending look at his dead bu Captain "ACE" ANGST. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puffing) Where'd they get you? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimaces) In the back...feels like an arrowhead. The BOMBARDIER looks at the co-pilot. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know he's dead? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, he looks dead. The bombardier raises the co-pilot's eyelid and confirms dead. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead, all right. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, give me a shot quick! The BOMBARDIER fumbles in the first-aid kit for a morphin While fixing syringe, BOMBARDIER looks down at back of Pi 68f  CU - SEAT We see two small jagged holes ripped in the back of the c 68g  CU - BOMBARDIER - LT. ZOGG He looks and frowns. 68h  MS - NAVIGATOR - LT. "BINKY" BALLMUFF LT. BALLMUFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct course to two-seven-three.  We should be about a hundred and forty miles away from Laputa.  Be there in about six- teen minutes. 68i  MASTER SHOT MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Binky, two-seven-three. (to LT. ZOGG) Lothar, any damage down below? Rolls up his sleeve. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what we got left besides Bim and Bam. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quentin, how's your gear? BOMBARDIER gives him shot. LT. QUENTIN QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you don't know? LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't checked.  I'm bleeding again. MAJOR KONG shakes his head in disappointment. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly and very John Wayne) The hydraulic systems out, Lothar, and a lot of wiring is hanging loose.  The number MAJOR KONG (Cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: one and three port engines are hit, and the fuel's leaking.  But we're still flying.  And what's more, we're going to carry out our mission. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking out over nose of plane) Look, Major.  What's that? 68j  DISTANT HORIZON - FORWARD Eight powerful aircraft searchlights cut long narrow stre the night sky.  But, instead of a steady beam, they are b on and off in fairly close unison. 68k  CU - MAJOR KONG Bravely trying to comprehend the distant lights. 68l  CU - BOMBARDIER - LT. LOTHAR ZOGG Screwing up his face in bewilderment. 68m  DISTANT VIEW - SEARCHLIGHTS BLINKING ON AND OFF 68n  CU - MAJOR KONG Narrows his eyes suspiciously. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I'll be damned. 68o  CU - BOMBARDIER - LT. ZOGG Staring blankly. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Yeah. 68p  TWO SHOT - KONG AND ZOGG Both men numbly stare at the distant searchlights. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into intercom) Binky, Quentin, Terry!  Come forward - quick! 68q  CUTS OF THE CREW SCRAMBLING TO COCKPIT 68r  THE GROUP - FAVORING PILOT LT. QUIFFER, LT. ZOGG, LT. BALLMUFF, and LT. TOEJAM crowd behind him. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. 68s  DISTANT VIEW OUT OVER INSTRUMENTS The searchlights continue their signaling. 68t  CU - LT. QUIFFER - PUZZLED 68u  CU - LT. BALLMUFF - PERPLEXED 68v  CU - LT. TOEJAM - CURIOUS 68w  MS - THE GROUP MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it look like? LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some kind of signaling. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncertainly) Let's see...International Morse, I think ...K...E...O...P...E...R...E...C...A...L... L...M...I...S...T...A...K...E...O...P...E... Gee, I don't know, it seems to be some kind of code. The negro bombardier, LT. LOTHAR ZOGG, has been jotting i LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, look!  It's "OPE - Recall Mistake." MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recall what mistake? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I think it means, "Recall period Mistake," and the OPE is probably the CRM-114 code. Terry? LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I'll go back and check my code book. He hops on his bad ankle back to his desk. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) You sure have to hand it to those guys. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean pulling a stunt like that. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? LT. TOEJAM hops forward again. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep, it's the CRM-114 code, all right. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very interesting. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we sure as hell aren't going home just because the enemy tells us to. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, Major.  "OPE," that's the recall code.  Where would they get that? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must have gotten it from the base. No one else would know it. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should they call us back? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell do I know?  Maybe the war's over. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered) Could be. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wistfully) I hope we won. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Zogg, what do our orders say about the authentication of orders during an attack mission? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, this is different. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our orders warn us to expect the enemy to use ingenuity in issuing contrary and confusing orders.  And therefore, to disregard anything that doesn't come on the CRM-114. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the CRM-114 has been smashed for almost an hour. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then that settles it, doesn't it? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell it does. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) The CRM-114 is smashed, right? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  So how could we get any messages? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ruffled) That's the point. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get you, King. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said that's the point! LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, King, maybe you've lost too much blood, or something. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explodes) Lieutentant Zogg, how would you like your black butt slung into a General Court Martial when we get back??? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Major Kong. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then get off my back! LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Major Kong's right, Lothar.  I mean we got the attack order from base, and Plan -R is an emergency plan for a base commander after a lot of other plans have been clobbered. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay!  You tell me how the enemy got the code! It's put in our sealed plans at the base just before we take off. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are plenty of traitors and spies running around loose. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the code is made up by General Ripper, and he's the only one left at the base who would know the code. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's loyalty is beyond question.  Besides, how do we know one of his staff didn't see it? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, King.  That doesn't make sense. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (triumphantly) Okay, how do we know they didn't shoot down one of our planes and torture the crew?  How do we know that? LT. ZOGG frowns. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the clincher) We crossed the coast over an hour ago. Okay? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after some thought) You're giving them an awful lot of credit for being on the ball. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First lesson in War College:  Never under- estimate your enemy. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Sorry, King. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.  Okay, team, let's break it up and get ready for the kick-off. The team scatters back to their stations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He anxiously flips switches, bangs panels with the palm o hand, curses to himself, and flips more switches.  Variou cuts to important-looking switches and warning lights. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King? 70a  MS - PILOT - MAJOR KONG Rocking in his seat and emitting soft groans. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me - Lothar.  Are you okay? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay.  What's up? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I hate to say this, but I think the bomb bay doors are stuck. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can't get out and look, King.  But I don't get a green light. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the warning system's out. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I get a red light. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you tried the emergency system? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried everything.  Something must have gotten bent or twisted from the pounding we took. 70b  CU - PILOT He stares out over the nose of the plane for several seco portentous look of valour seems to overcome the pain. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lothar, can you arm the bombs for impact? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I TOLD YOU, I don't think we can get the bomb bay doors open. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you a question, Lothar! LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how are we going to drop the bombs if the doors won't --- (the penny drops) Hey, King....you're not thinking of --- You don't mean you'd --- ??? 70c  CUTS TO OTHER CREW MEMBERS AS THEY REALIZE THE PLAN MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) There's no other way, Lothar.  Can you re-arm the bombs for impact? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned silence) Let me check. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no other way, boys.  I'm going to have to take her in...the hard way. 70d  CUTS TO CREW - HORRIFIED, SWEATING, TREMBLING LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, King.  If there was any way I could help, I wouldn't think of asking, but would you mind if I bailed out. MAJOR KONG is clearly hurt by this lack of comradeship. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) No, I wouldn't mind, Lieutenant Quiffer. 70e  CUTS TO FRIGHTENED AND CONFUSED CREW LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncertainly) I think it's okay, King.  They should go off on impact. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (audaciously) Would it matter if they hit at a flat angle? I mean, do you think the deuterium mass might separate from the atomic trigger? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faintly) Well, it would probably help if you took it ...sort of...straight down. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger. The other crew members unhappily watch the D.S.O., LT. QUIFFER, prepare to bail out.  His leg seems to have unst He pauses long enough to notice his buddies. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, King, maybe the other boys don't think it right to ask, so I'm asking for them.  Can they bail out too? MAJOR KONG stiffens at this last shattering of camaraderi MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in an angry sulk) Anyone that wants to save his neck certainly ought to. The other crew members hastily get ready to jump. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, we hate to leave you like this, Major Kong.  But there isn't anything we can really accomplish by sticking around. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Forget it. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, listen, King.  Could you take her up to about eight hundred?  That'll help you come in at a nice down-angle, and it'll give us a chance for our chutes to open. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Sure, I'll take her up to eight hundred. LT. QUIFFER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you take her up right now, King?  Other- wise we'll get kind of close to the fireball. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Sure, I'll take her up right now. He pulls up the nose of the plane sharply.  The men get r

dialogues.speaker: B-90 CLIMBING
dialogues.text: As it reaches eight hundred feet, enemy radar, hitherto p from tracking the plane due to its low-level tactics, sud zeros in, and all kinds of flak and tracer fire open up. LT. TOEJAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, King, old buddy.  On behalf--- MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip it and jump, damn you!  This flak's so close, I can smell it. The crew bails out. AD LIBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they go) Good luck, King! God bless you, King! Geronimo! MAJOR KONG starts to fly evasive tactics through the flak

dialogues.speaker: MS
dialogues.text: LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) We're on course, Major.  Just fixed our position on that river back there. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing here, Lothar? The two men are deeply touched by this Stanley Kramer-ish moment of truth. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with masculine simplicity) I thought I'd go along for the ride. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (John Wayne) Now what the hell did you want to go and do a thing like that for, Lothar? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you'd like some company. MAJOR KONG punches him in the arm. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sure was a hell of a stupid thing to do. The flak rocks the plane, and the lights of the city ahea continue to flash. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King, would you mind if I keep me hands on the wheel when you take her in? MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (John Wayne - all the way) I'd be mighty proud if you did, Lothar. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, King.  I've always wanted to take one of these big babies in. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Lothar.  You know that crack I made about your...butt? LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted you to know I didn't mean anything by it. LT. ZOGG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, King. MAJOR KONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I just wanted you to know how I felt. Hell, I know Air Command wouldn't have taken you if you weren't okay.  And don't think I don't know some of our best ball-players and entertainers are of Negro descent.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: (TRICK SHOT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a tremendous thermonuclear explosion caused by t megaton H-bombs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is predictably gloomy and philosophical.  It sho apparent they've heard the news. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head, miserably) It's wrong. (sighs) It's dead wrong. ADMIRAL BULDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head, wretchedly) It's not right. No one is really talking to anyone else. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignant) I don't care what anyone says, it just doesn't seem to make sense to end all human life on Earth. ADMIRAL BULDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose the fishes will take over the world. GENERAL FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh-hhhh, that's a horrible thought. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all so pointless.  I mean a man works his whole life fighting for something, and this is what he gets. (bitterly) You know, I can see twenty, forty, a hundred million - but everybody?  It's just a damned shame, and I don't mind saying so. The PRESIDENT sits alone in the corner of the room.  He s nothing. ZLAT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (responsibility weighs heavy) Mister President, how are we going to break it to the people?  I mean it's going to do one hell of a thing to your image. The PRESIDENT shrugs, irritably. VON KLUTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with Germanic coolness) Mister Ambassador, how long will it take? The AMBASSADOR looks up, wearily. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing with both hands) Four - possibly six months in the Northern Hemispheres.  Perhaps a year in the Southern latitudes. VON KLUTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wiping his steel-rimmed glasses) Mister President, I wouldnot rule out the chance to preserve a nucleus of human specimens, at the bottom shafts of some of our deepest mines. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tiredly) At the bottom of mines? VON KLUTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully putting on glasses) Yes.  The radioactivity could not penetrate a mine some thousands of feet deep. The PRESIDENT looks blankly at VON KLUTZ. VON KLUTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a matter of weeks, sufficient improvements for a dwelling space could be provided. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they couldn't come out for a hundred years! VON KLUTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling wisely) Mister President, man is an amazingly adaptable creature.  After all, the conditions would be far superior to those, say, of the Nazi concentration camps, where there is ample evidence most of the wretched creatures clung desperately to life. Although the PRESIDENT seems unconvinced, looking around room, it is apparent VON KLUTZ's proposal has not fallen deaf ears. VON KLUTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling modestly) It would not be difficult.  Nuclear reactors could provide power almost indefinitely. Greenhouses could maintain plant life. Animals could be bred and slaughtered. A quick survey would have to be made of all the suitable minesites in the country, but I shouldn't be surprised if several hundred thousand of our people could be accomodatedd. Every nation would undoubtedly follow suit. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But who would be chosen? VON KLUTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A special committee would have to be appointed to study and recommend the criteria to be employed, but off-hand, I should say that in addition to the factors of youth, health, sexual fertility, intelligence, and a cross-section of necessary skills, it would be absolutely vital that our top government and military men be included, to impart the required principles of leadership and tradition. The arrow has not missed its mark, and there is an outbre sober, nodding heads. VON KLUTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs, distastefully) Naturally, they would breed prodigiously, eh? There would be much time and little to do. With the proper breeding techniques, and starting with a ratio of, say, ten women to each man, I should estimate the progeny of the original group of 200,000 would emerge a hundred years later as well over a hundred million.  Naturally the group would have to continually engage in enlarging the original living space. Much serious judgment is brought to bear around the table are brought into action. VON KLUTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they emerge, a good deal of present real estate and machine tools will still be recoverable, if they are moth-balled in advance.  I would guess they could then work their way back to our present gross national product within twenty years. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, look here, Von Klutz.  Won't this nucleus of survivors be so shocked, grief-stricken, and anguished that they will envy the dead, and indeed, not wish to go on living? VON KLUTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not, sir.  When they go down into the mine, everyone else will still be alive.  They will have no shocking memories, and the prevailing emotion should be one of a nostalgia for those VON KLUTZ (Cont)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: left behind, combined with a spirit of bold curiousity for the adventure ahead. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (judiciously) You mentioned the ratio of ten women to each man.  Wouldn't that necessitate abandoning the so-called monogamous form of sexual relation- ship? VON KLUTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regrettably, yes.  But it is a sacrifice required for the future of the human race.  I hasten to add that since each man will be required to perform prodigious service along these lines, the women will have to be selected for their sexual characteristics, which will have to be of a highly stimulating order. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically) Von Klutz, I must confess you have an astonish- ingly good idea there. VON KLUTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (correctly) Thank you, sir. AMBASSADOR DE SADE rises. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (briskly) And now, Mister President, I must return at once to my embassy to communicate this reassuring news to the Premier. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) Goodbye, Mister Ambassador. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the door) We have many splendidly deep mines in our country. He exits. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Mister President, I think we've got to look into this thing from the military point of view. I mean, if the enemy stashed away some big bombs and we didn't, when they come out in a hundred years, they could take over. GENERAL FACEMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, sir.  In fact, they might even try a quick, sneak attack, so they can take over our mine-shaft space. ADMIRAL BULDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They might even try to knock over a couple of other countries and take their mine-shaft space.  If they had more mine-shaft space than we did, they could breed more, and possibly take over when they come out. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must not allow a mine-shaft gap!! The phone rings.  ADMIRAL BULDIKE picks it up. ADMIRAL BULDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?...Yes, just a minute. (to GENERAL SCHMUCK) It's personal. GENERAL SCHMUCK takes the phone. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (charmingly) Yes?...Well, pretty soon, dear. Yes, I've finished my business.  Uh-huh... Uh-huh... (laughs) Yes, dear.  Same here.  Bye-bye. Hangs up the phone. There is a knock at the door.  Enter AMBASSADOR DE SADE. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (haughtily) Excuse me, Mister President, but you forgot to give me my camera back. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fishes in pocket for Minox) Oh, yes, that's right. GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a second, sir.  He's got films of the War Room in that thing! PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I'll have to ask you to take the film out. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Very well. GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, sir, that camera might be a dummy he wanted us to find.  He's probably got another one secreted on his person. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sputtering) That's utterly ridiculous. GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been here for almost two hours, and Lord knows what he's photographed.  I'd have him stripped and give a thorough body search. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appalled) That's preposterous!  I object!! The PRESIDENT thinks for a moment. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reassuringly) I'm afraid we'll have to - purely as a formality, Ambassador de Sade.  Zlat, will you call the Secret Service and have them prepare a private room upstairs for a body search. The AMBASSADOR is shocked and angry. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mister President, I am extremely shy and do not wish to endure this sort of personal humiliation.  Here is the only other camera I have left. (he produces a second camera) GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See!  See, I told you. PRESIDENT MUFFLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) You've lied to me twice - I'm sorry, but it will be strictly routine.  These men are experts. GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zlat, make sure the secret service boys care- fully search his seven body orifices. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified) My seven body orifices???? GENERAL SCHMUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, fella. AMBASSADOR DE SADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touches ears) One, two... (touches each nostril) three, four... (touches mouth) five... (freezes, turns red and swallows hard) Why you, dirty, stinking... AMBASSADOR DE SADE picks up a thick custard pie from amon large selection of pies previously brought into the room and smashes it into GENERAL SCHMUCK's angry face. GENERAL SCHMUCK hurls a coconut cream pie at DE SADE, who It splatters into the face of ADMIRAL PERCY BULDIKE. Not realizing why he has been hit, ADMIRAL PERCY BULDIKE a chocolate cream pie at GENERAL "BUCK" SCHMUCK.  It miss plops into PRESIDENT MUFFLEY's face. And, as is the case with the great-pie throwing scenes, m ing piles upon misunderstanding, until everyone in the ro ally engaged in splattering pies into each other's face.

dialogues.speaker: PULL AWAY FROM PLANET EARTH
dialogues.text: into outer space.  (A reverse of the opening shot) NARRATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though the little-known, dead planet Earth, remotely situated in the Milky Way Galaxy, is admittedly of little interest to us today, we have presented this quaint comedy of Galaxy pre-history, when the primitive organization of sovereign nation states still flourished, and the archaic institution of War had not yet been forbidden by Law, as another in our series, "The Dead Worlds of Antiquity." Macro-Galaxy-Meteor Pictures T H E  E N D
